1) // 2] += 1 # Add both filters.h = hlpf + hhpf ä¸€ä¸ªç®€å•çš„åº”ç”¨ç¤ºä¾‹#!/usr/bin/env python3import numpy as np def lowFIR(fc = 0.1, b = 0.08): #fc: Cutoff frequency as a fraction of the sampling rate (in (0, 0.5)). #b: Transition band, as a fraction of the sampling rate (in (0, 0.5)). N = int(np.ceil((4 / b))) if not N % 2: N += 1 # Make sure that N is odd. n = np.arange(N) # Compute sinc filter. h = np.sinc(2 * fc * (n - (N - 1) / 2)) # Compute Blackman window. w = 0.42 - 0.5 * np.cos(2 * np.pi * n / (N - 1)) + \ 0.08 * np.cos(4 * np.pi * n / (N - 1)) # Multiply sinc filter by window. h = h * w # Normalize to get unity gain. h = h / np.sum(h) # Create a high-pass filter from the low-pass filter through spectral inversion. h *= - 1 h[(N - 1) // 2] += 1 return N, h#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------def passFIR(fL = 0.1, fH = 0.4, b = 0.08): N = int(np.ceil(4 / b)) if not N % 2: N += 1 n = np.arange(N) hlpf = np.sinc(2 * fH * (n - (N - 1) / 2)) hlpf *= np.blackman(N) hlpf /= np.sum(hlpf) hhpf = np.sinc(2 * fL * (n - (N - 1) / 2)) hhpf *= np.blackman(N) hhpf /= np.sum(hhpf) hhpf *= - 1 hhpf[(N - 1) // 2] += 1 h = np.convolve(hlpf, hhpf) return 2*N - 1, h#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------def stopFIR(fL = 0.1, fH = 0.4, b = 0.08): N = int(np.ceil(4 / b)) if not N % 2: N += 1 n = np.arange(N) hlpf = np.sinc(2 * fL * (n - (N - 1) / 2)) hlpf *= np.blackman(N) hlpf /= np.sum(hlpf) hhpf = np.sinc(2 * fH * (n - (N - 1) / 2)) hhpf *= np.blackman(N) hhpf /= np.sum(hhpf) hhpf *= - 1 hhpf[(N - 1) // 2] += 1 h = hlpf + hhpf return N, h#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------import matplotlib.pyplot as pltfs = 1000 # sampling frequency# generate properly the time vectort = np.arange(1000)/fssga = np.sin(2*np.pi*2*t) # signal with f = 2sgb = np.sin(2*np.pi*6*t) # signal with f = 6sgc = np.sin(2*np.pi*10*t) # signal with f = 10sgd = sga + sgcsge = sga + sgb + sgcif 1: plt.plot(t, sga, label = 'f = 2') plt.plot(t, sgc, label = 'f = 10') plt.plot(t, sgd, label = 'f = 2 + 10') N, h = lowFIR(fc = 5/fs, b = 2/fs) sgf = np.convolve(sgd, h) plt.plot(t, sgf[int(N/2):1000 + int(N/2)], label = 'low-pass') N, h = highFIR(fc = 5/fs, b = 2/fs) sgf = np.convolve(sgd, h) plt.plot(t, sgf[int(N/2):1000 + int(N/2)], label = 'high-pass')else: plt.plot(t, sgb, label = 'f = 6') plt.plot(t, sgd, label = 'f = 2 + 10') plt.plot(t, sge, label = 'f = 2 + 6 + 10') N, h = passFIR(fL = 4/fs, fH = 8/fs, b = 1/fs) sgf = np.convolve(sge, h) plt.plot(t, sgf[int(N/2):1000 + int(N/2)], label = 'band-pass') N, h = stopFIR(fL = 4/fs, fH = 8/fs, b = 1/fs) sgf = np.convolve(sge, h) plt.plot(t, sgf[int(N/2):1000 + int(N/2)], label = 'band-stop')plt.legend()plt.show()

Hilbert å˜æ¢å®šä¹‰å‚è€ƒ Wikipedia ã€‚ The Hilbert transform of the function $u(t)$ can be thought of as the convolution of $u(t)$ with the function $h(t)= rac{1}{\pi t}$. Because $h(t)$ is not integrable, the integrals defining the convolution do not converge. Instead, the Hilbert transform is defined using the Cauchy principal value (denoted here by $p$ ): $$\mathcal{H}\lbrace u(t)brace=p\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}u(	au)h(t-	au)d	au= rac{1}{\pi}p\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} rac{u(	au)}{t-	au}d	au$$ æ€§è´¨A property of Hilbert transform is: $\mathcal{H}\lbrace\mathcal{H}\lbrace u(t)bracebrace=-u(t)$. è§£æžä¿¡å·The analytic signal is constructed from a real signal $f(t)$ and its Hilbert transform $\mathcal{H}\lbrace f(t)brace$ : $$	ilde f(t)=f(t)-i\mathcal H\lbrace f(t)brace$$ The analytic signal can be written in terms of the instantaneous amplitude $E(t)$ and the instantaneous phase $\phi(t)$ as $$	ilde f(t)=E(t)e^{i\phi(t)}$$ where $$\phi(t)=\arctan rac{\mathfrak I\lbrace	ilde f(t)brace}{\mathfrak R\lbrace	ilde f(t)brace}=\arctan rac{\mathcal H\lbrace f(t)brace}{f(t)}$$ $$E(t)=\sqrt{\mathfrak R\lbrace	ilde f(t)brace^2+\mathfrak I\lbrace	ilde f(t)brace^2}=\sqrt{f(t)^2+\mathcal H\lbrace f(t)brace^2}$$ å…±è½­è½¬ç½®å®šä¹‰åˆç§° Hermitian è½¬ç½®ã€‚å‚è€ƒ Wikipedia ã€‚ In mathematics, the conjugate transpose and Hermitian transpose of an $m	imes n$ matrix $A$ with complex entries is the $n	imes m$ matrix $A^*$ obtained from $A$ by taking the transpose and then taking the complex conjugate of each entry. The definition can also be written as $$A^*=( ar{A})^T=\overline{A^T}$$ The commonly used symbols for the conjugate transpose: $A^*$ or $A^H$ in linear algebra ; $A^\dagger$ in quantum mechanics ; $A^+$. ä¾‹å­If $A= egin{bmatrix} 1 & -2-i 
ewline 1+i & i \end{bmatrix} $, then $A^*= egin{bmatrix} 1 & 1-i 
ewline -2+i & -i \end{bmatrix}$. Kronecker ä¹˜ç§¯å®šä¹‰å‚è€ƒ Wikipedia ã€‚ In mathematics, the Kronecker product, denoted by $\otimes$, is an operation on two matrices of arbitrary size resulting in a block matrix. It is a generalization of the outer product from vectors to matrices. If $A$ is an $m	imes n$ matrix and $B$ is a $p	imes q$ matrix, then the Kronecker product $A\otimes B$ is the $mp	imes nq$ block matrix: $$A\otimes B=\left[ egin{array}{c} a_{11}B & a_{12}B & \cdots & a_{1n}B 
ewline a_{21}B & a_{22}B & \cdots & a_{2n}B 
ewline \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots

ewline a_{ij}b_{21} & a_{ij}b_{22} & \cdots & a_{ij}b_{2q} 
ewline \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots 
ewline a_{ij}b_{p1} & a_{ij}b_{p2} & \cdots & a_{ij}b_{pq} \end{array} ight]$$ ä¾‹å­$$\left[ egin{array}{c} 1 & 2 
ewline 3 & 4 \end{array}ight] \otimes \left[ egin{array}{c} 0 & 5 
ewline 6 & 7 \end{array}ight]=\left[ egin{array}{c} 1\cdot \left[ egin{array}{c} 0 & 5 
ewline 6 & 7 \end{array}ight] & 2\cdot \left[ egin{array}{c} 0 & 5 
ewline 6 & 7 \end{array}ight] 
ewline 3\cdot \left[ egin{array}{c} 0 & 5 
ewline 6 & 7 \end{array}ight] & 4\cdot \left[ egin{array}{c} 0 & 5

ewline 6 & 7 & 12 & 14 
ewline 0 & 15 & 0 & 20 
ewline 18 & 21 & 24 & 28 \end{array}ight]$$ Frobenius èŒƒæ•°å®šä¹‰ä¹Ÿå³ Hilbert-Schmidt èŒƒæ•°ã€‚å‚è€ƒ Wikipedia ã€‚ The norm can be defined in various ways: $$||A||_F=\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^m\sum_{j=1}^n|a_{ij}|^2}=\sqrt{trace(A^\dagger A)}=\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{\min\lbrace m,nbrace}\sigma_i^2(A)}$$ where $A^\dagger$ denotes the conjugate transpose of $A$, and $\sigma_i(A)$ are the singular value of $A$. Frobenius å†…ç§¯å‚è€ƒ Wikipedia ã€‚ $$||A||_F=\sqrt{\langle A,Aangle_F}$$ where the Frobenius inner product is defined by: $$\langle A,Bangle_F=\sum_{i,j}\overline{A_{ij}}B_{ij}=trace(\overline{A^T}B)$$ Hadamard ä¹˜ç§¯å®šä¹‰ä¹Ÿå³ Hadamard matrices ã€‚å‚è€ƒ Wikipedia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadamard_product_(matrices) ã€‚ For two matrices, $A, B$, of the same dimension, $m	imes n$, the Hadamard product, $A\circ B$, is a matrix of the same dimension as the operands, with elements given by $$(A\circ B)_{i,j}=A_{i,j}B_{i,j}$$ The Hadamard division $A\oslash B$ is defined as: $$(A\oslash B)_{ij}= rac{A_{ij}}{B_{ij}}$$ æ€§è´¨ The Hadamard product is commutative, associative and distributive over addition, that is: $A\circ B=B\circ A$ $A\circ(B\circ C)=(A\circ B)\circ C$ $A\circ(B+C)=A\circ B+A\circ C$ For square matrices $A, B$, the row-sums of their Hadamard product are the diagonal elements of $AB^T$ or $B^TA$: $\sum_i(A\circ B)_{i,j}=(B^TA)_{j,j}$ $\sum_j(A\circ B)_{i,j}=(AB^T)_{i,i}$ Hilbert çŸ©é˜µå®šä¹‰å‚è€ƒ Wikipedia ã€‚ In linear algebra, a Hilbert matrix is a square matrix with entries being the unit fractions: $$H_{ij}= rac{1}{i+j-1}$$ For example, this is the $3	imes 3$ Hilbert matrix: $$H=\left[ egin{array}{c} 1 &  rac{1}{2} &  rac{1}{3} 
ewline  rac{1}{2} &  rac{1}{3} &  rac{1}{4} 
ewline  rac{1}{3} &  rac{1}{4} &  rac{1}{5} \end{array}ight]$$ åº”ç”¨The notoriously ill-conditioned Hilbert matrix can be defined as: $$J_{ij}:= egin{cases}  rac{1}{i+j-1} & 	ext{if }i	ext{ mod }j=0	ext{, or }j	ext{ mod }i=0 
ewline 0 & 	ext{otherwise} \end{cases}$$ For example, if given by $n=5â€‹$, the matrix $Jâ€‹$ has the condition number of $4.9	imes 10^3â€‹$. çŸ©é˜µçš„æ¡ä»¶æ•°çŸ©é˜µ $A$ çš„æ¡ä»¶æ•°ï¼ˆcondition numberï¼‰å¯å®šä¹‰ä¸ºï¼š $$\kappa(A)=||A||\cdot ||A^{-1}||$$ å¦‚æžœæ–¹é˜µ $A$ æ˜¯å¥‡å¼‚çš„ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆ $A$ çš„æ¡ä»¶æ•°ä¸ºæ­£æ— ç©·å¤§ã€‚å®žé™…ä¸Šï¼Œæ¯ä¸€ä¸ªå¯é€†æ–¹é˜µéƒ½å­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªæ¡ä»¶æ•°ã€‚ æ¡ä»¶æ•°æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªçŸ©é˜µï¼ˆæˆ–å®ƒæ‰€æè¿°çš„çº¿æ€§ç³»ç»Ÿï¼‰çš„ç¨³å®šæ€§æˆ–æ•æ„Ÿåº¦çš„åº¦é‡ã€‚ A problem with a low condition number is said to be well-conditioned, while a problem with a high condition number is said to be ill-conditioned. ç§¯åˆ†å‡½æ•°è¡¨å‚è€ƒ Wikipediaã€‚ æœ‰ç†å‡½æ•° æŒ‡æ•°å‡½æ•° å¯¹æ•°å‡½æ•° ä¸‰è§’å‡½æ•° åä¸‰è§’å‡½æ•° åŒæ›²å‡½æ•° ååŒæ›²å‡½æ•° å¦å¤–ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œè¿˜æœ‰åœ¨çº¿æ•°å­¦ç¬”è®°ã€‚ ç‹„æ‹‰å…‹æ¢³çŠ¶å‡½æ•°å³ Dirac comb æˆ– Shah å‡½æ•°ï¼Œå‚è€ƒ Wikipedia ã€‚ åœ¨æ•°å­¦ä¸Šï¼ŒDirac comb å³ä¸€ä¸ªç”± Dirac delta å‡½æ•°æž„æˆçš„å‘¨æœŸæ€§è°ƒå’Œåˆ†å¸ƒï¼ˆperiodic tempered distributionï¼‰ã€‚ä¹Ÿå³ç”µå­å·¥ç¨‹ä¸­çš„è„‰å†²åºåˆ—ï¼ˆimpulse trainï¼‰æˆ–é‡‡æ ·å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆsampling functionï¼‰ã€‚ A Dirac comb is an infinite series of Dirac delta functions spaced at intervals of $T$. å‡½æ•°è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸ºï¼š $$III_T(t)=\sum_{k=-\infty}^\infty \delta (t-kT)$$ å‡½æ•°å›¾åƒå¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

BFGS ç®—æ³•ä¹Ÿå³ Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno ç®—æ³•ã€‚å‚è€ƒ Wikipedia ã€‚ åŽŸç†The search direction at stage $k$ is given by the Newton method: $$p_k=-B_k
abla f(x_k)$$ where $B_k$ is an approximation of the Hessian matrix, and $
abla f(x_k)$ is the gradient of the function at $x_k$ The quasi-Newton condition imposed on the update of $B_k$ is: $$B_{k+1}(x_{k+1}-x_k)=
abla f(x_{k+1})-
abla f(x_k)$$ Let $y_k=

abla f(x_k)$ and $s_k=x_{k+1}-x_k$, then $B_{k+1}s_k=y_k$ which is the secant equation. The curvature condition $s_k^Ty_k>0$ should be satisfied. abla f(x_k)$; Perform a line search to find an acceptable stepsize $\alpha_k$ in the direction found in the first step; Set $s_k=\alpha_kp_k$ and update $x_{k+1}=x_k+s_k$; $y_k=
abla f(x_{k+1})-

Fixed point è¿­ä»£æ³•Fixed pointå‚è€ƒ Wikipedia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixed_point_(mathematics) ã€‚ Not to be confused with a stationary point where $fâ€™(x)=0$ . In mathematics, $c$ is a fixed point of the function $f(x)$ if $f(c) = c$. Points that come back to the same value after a finite number of iterations of the function are called periodic points. A fixed point is a periodic point with period equal to one. Fixed point è¿­ä»£å®šä¹‰å‚è€ƒ Wikipedia ã€‚ In numerical analysis, given a function $f$ defined on the real number with real values and given a point $x_0$ in the domain of $f$, the fixed point iteration is $$x_{n+1}=f(x_n), n=0,1,2,â€¦$$ åº”ç”¨Newtonâ€™s method for finding roots of a given differentiable function $f(x)$ is $$x_{n+1}=x_n- rac{f(x_n)}{fâ€™(x_n)}$$ If we write $g(x)=x- rac{f(x)}{fâ€™(x)}$, we may rewrite the Newton iteration as $$x_{n+1}=g(x_n)$$ If this iteration converges to a fixed point $x$ of $g$, then $$x=g(x)=x- rac{f(x)}{fâ€™(x)}$$ so that $$ rac{f(x)}{fâ€™(x)}=0$$ The reciprocal of anything is nonzero, therefore $f(x)=0$: $x$ is a root of $f$. éžçº¿æ€§å…±è½­æ¢¯åº¦æ³•å‚è€ƒ Wikipedia ã€‚ In numerical optimization, the nonlinear conjugate gradient method generalizes the conjugate gradient method to nonlinear optimization. çº¿æ€§å…±è½­æ¢¯åº¦æ³•For a quadratic function $$f(x)=||Ax-b||^2$$ the minimum of $f$ is obtained when the gradient $
abla_x f=2A^T(Ax-b)=0$. Linear conjugate gradient seeks a solution to the linear equation $A^T Ax=A^T b$. éžçº¿æ€§å…±è½­æ¢¯åº¦æ³•The nonlinear conjugate gradient method is generally used to find the local minimum of a nonlinear function using its gradient $
abla_x f$ alone. ç®—æ³•æ­¥éª¤Given a function $f(x)$, one simply starts in the steepest descent direction: $$\Delta x_0=-
abla_x f(x_0)$$ with an step length $\alpha$, and preforms a line search: $$\alpha_0:=argmin_\alpha f(x_0+\alpha\Delta x_0)$$ $$x_1=x_0+\alpha_0\Delta x_0$$ After the first iteration in $\Delta x_0$, the following steps continue along a subsequent conjugate direction $s_n$, where $s_0=\Delta x_0$: Calculate the steepest direction: $\Delta x_n=-
abla_x f(x_n)$; Compute $ eta_n$ according to one of the formulas below; Update the conjugate direction: $s_n=\Delta x_n+ eta_n s_{n-1}$; Perform a line search: optimize $\alpha_n=argmin_\alpha f(x_n+\alpha s_n)$; Update: $x_{n+1}=x_n+\alpha_n s_n$. Subsequent search directions lose conjugacy requiring the searchdirection to be reset to the steepest descent direction at least every $N$ iterations, or sooner if progress stops. $ eta_n$ çš„è®¡ç®—Four of the best known formulas for $ eta_nâ€‹$ are named after their developers: Fletcher-Reeves: $ eta_n^{FR}= rac{\Delta x_n^T \Delta x_n}{\Delta x_{n-1}^T \Delta x_{n-1}}$; Polak-Ribiere: $ eta_n^{PR}= rac{\Delta x_n^T (\Delta x_n-\Delta x_{n-1})}{\Delta x_{n-1}^T \Delta x_{n-1}}$; Hestenes-Stiefel: $ eta_n^{HS}=- rac{\Delta x_n^T (\Delta x_n-\Delta x_{n-1})}{s_{n-1}^T (\Delta x_n-\Delta x_{n-1})}$; Dai-Yuan: $ eta_n^{DY}=- rac{\Delta x_n^T \Delta x_n}{s_{n-1}^T (\Delta x_n-\Delta x_{n-1})}$. A popular choice is $ eta=\max\lbrace 0, eta^{PR}brace$, which provides a direction reset automatically.
